THEATRE HOPKINS OPEN •
Dr. Fagin: College Drama Made Debut Last Night
Dr. N. Bryllion Fagin, Associate Professor Emeritus of English and Drama,
Stated in an interview Wednesday that
theatre and drama must be regarded
as an integral part of the humanities,
Lkd that the university must endeavor
to "keep alive" the traditions in the fine
The former chairman of the now
defunct Drama Department added that
College theatre is becoming increasingly
knportant as a "training ground for
the future."
Dr. Fagin was appointed Assistant
Professor 'of English after he obtained
kds doctorate in English here in 1932.
His interest in the theatre stems from
his early years in New York. He began
studying English at Michigan Agricultural College and later transferred to
George Washington University where
he obtained his BA in English. He then
attended Columbia for a short time
until finances caused him to return to
George Washington and attend afternoon classes while working for the government.
After getting his MA, Dr. Fagin came
to Baltimore to teach at the University
Of Maryland School of Medicine and
Dentistry. He became an instructor in
American drama at Hopkins in 1926
and was chosen as director for the
Playshop.
Pounded by the English department
in 1921, the Playshop existed primarily
for the purpose of providing quality
Plays for the faculty and student body.
It soon developed into a community
theatre when alumni began to return to
take active part in the various productions. Dr. Fagin ranks the Playshop as
setni-professional since he feels that
many of the actors are good enough
to play professionally. He recalls when
each year the Playshop would award
a Prize to the author in the group with
the best original play and maintains
that New York scouts would come to
review the productions.
Dr. Fagin was chairman of the Drama
department during the ten years of its
existence. It was abolished several years
ago, at the request of the English de-.
Partment, probably because of the qUes'Lion of expense necessary to maintain
a good graduate school in drama.
The Playshop had no connection with
the undergraduate Barnstormers. With
both groups sharing the Barn, some
Problems arose in schedule and budget
— the Playshop was not reeeiving subsidy and had to charge admission to
its productions. Dr. Fagin believes that
the Barnstormers has had a positive efrect on the undergraduates. For some
Years, members of the Barnstormers
With high aspirations would take
Courses from the Department and would
also work with the Playshop. This re-

stilted in an intermingling between the
two groups.
With the union of the two dramatic
organizations resulting in Theatre Hopkins, Dr. Fagin said that some things
have been lost — such as the group enthusiasm which the Playshop had. The
Barnstormers would change every four
years, while the Playshop had a "sense
of permanance" with its nucleus of permanent members. He does think, how-

Theatre Hopkins, under the direction
of Edward Golden, Jr., opened its initial
season last night with Eugene Ionesco's
"The Killer." The play, being presented
at the Barn, will run thru November 7.
Last spring, at a time when Hopkins
drama was in danger of being extinguished due to lack of support, administration officials, led by Dean G. Wilson
Shaffer and executive to the president
Ross Jones, obtained Golden to direct

THEATRE Hopkins began it's fall season last night with Eugene
Ionesco's "The Killer

ever, that the new group will be able
to produce more plays with a greater
versatility.
The greatest problem facing Theatre
Hopkins now is the need for better facilities. Although according to Dr.
Fagin, "There are good attributes connected with a small theatre," he said the
Barn is not flexible enough to provide
for the kind of experimental plays Mr.
Golden and the Theatre hope to produce. What he feels is needed is a new
small theatre of the Shakespearean
type.
Dr. Fagin does not expect any outside financial grant for a resident Hopkins theatre group, although he admitted that the donation of a new theatre
would be a great help.

Hopkins dramatics, and then gave him
their full support for establishing Theatre Hopkins. In a recent interview,
Jones stated, "The administration is enthusiastic about the idea of Theatre
Hopkins, and is also pleased with the
several plays produced last summer by
Rick Wesley. University officials are
hopeful that the new Theatre Hopkins
plan will result in a quality company
of benefit both to the University environment and the city in general."
The newly created Theatre Hopkins
is a synthesis of the Barnstormers and
the Playshop, last year manned by undergraduate and graduates, respectively.
Through the union of the two groups,
director Golden hopes to carry out
many theatrical innovations that he
was unable to implement at the Centre
Stage.
"The Hopkins communi0 is the hope

for a Baltimore theatre," he stated. "In
my experience, a good many of the
people who support cultural activity are
doing it because it is socially acceptable.
With respect to resident theatres,
Golden explained that "the problem is
that the theatre eventually goes begging to the complacent moneyed people.
The theatre than becomes subservient
and does not want to antagonize its
audience."
Professor Richard Macksey, of the
Writing Seminars, expressed his opinion that the academic community is
the one hope for experimental theatre.
He feels that the choice and sequence
of the plays to be presented especially
lend themselves of such experimentation. According to Macksey," The Days
and Nights of Beebee Fenstermaker' has
great potental — Mr. Golden exercised
good judgment in placing it at the end
of the year, when the less experienced
actors will have gained some of the
necessary background for the main
roles."
Macksey foresee:; that the potential
success of Theatre Hopkins may result
in a more permanent theatrical arrangement, possibly subsidized by the
Equity foundation or some other private
organization, or perhaps through the
Congressional Arts and Humanities Bill.
Such financial support would enable
the Theatre to employ some professional actors, and would present even greater opportunities for experiment.
From a purely practical standpoint,
according to Golden, the combination
of the Barnstormers and the Playshop
will alleviate many of the organizational problems encountered previously
when both groups were forced to produce plays into the Barn. In addition,
he believes that the inexperienced undergraduate actors will benefit from the
contact with the more experienced
members of the Playshop, which may
be considered as being on the semiprofessional level.
In addition to Theatre Hopkins, undergraduates will have the opportunity
to participate in two independently produced Barnstormer presentations, the
freshman play and Hopkins' latest musical, "The Boys from Syracuse."
While Theatre Hopkins will operate
during the fall and spring semesters,
the independent Homewood Summer
Theatre will present plays during the
summer months, completing the yearround schedule of theatrical performances presented on the Johns Hopkins
campus.
The. Homewood Summer Theatre
came into being last summer, largely
through the determined efforts of Rick
Wessler, currently a senior at Hopkins.
At that time it became apparent that
the annual summer Playshop would be
unable to function as it had for the
past thirty-four years due to the lack
of a director. Wessler secured permission from the Hopkins administration
to use the facilities of the Barn, and
with a total contribution from the faculty of $5.00, proceeded,to launch
successful season.

CAMPUS NOTES
Movie Mixers
The first YMCA mixer will be
held immediately after tonight's
mm, "Beat The Devil." To be
held in the New Addition of the
Great Hall, the mixer will feature a live band. It will begin at
9:130 P.m., or when the movie is
over. Girls from the major colleges and nurses' homes in the
area are expected to attend.
Admission to those who want
to attend the movie and the
Mixer is $1.00. YMCA general
and combined membership holders will be admitted free, as will
girls holding college I.D. cards.
The mixer will end at 12:00
Midnight. During the mixer "The
Room At The Top" coffee house
Will be open, serving coffee and
hot cider.

Short Lecture

1. 8:00 p.m., the Levering Hall
YMCA will present Robert L.
Short, author of the popular
book, The Gospel According To
13,eanufs. Mr. short is graduate

With his lectures, illustrated with

n the theological implications
111 Peanuts.
Mr. Short's lecture at Hopkins
Is made possible by the funds

each year in the general area of

Other Jeffery lecturers this year
include Saul Altnsky, Carl MtChalsori, and Bayard Rustin,

Ski Club
The newly formed Johns Hopkins Ski Club will hold its next
fleeting on Wednesday, Nov. 10
at 8 P.M. in the classroom seeof the Athletic Center. Open
t° both undergraduate and gradfate students, the Ski Club wlil
be affiliated with the U.S. Eastern Amateur Skiing Association
and the Baltimore Ski Club.
Official sanction for the club
eas been obtained from the UniVersity and the Athletic Depart°lent, and at a recent organi
Zational meeting, 32 students exDressed interest in joining. A $5
Inembership fee will provide for
altbscription to various publications, discounts from ski shops,
reduction of lift tickets, and free
ski lessons by accredited instructors for inexperienced members.
Trips are scheduled to nearby
,
81(1
areas, including Oregon
Ltidge, and the club will form a
_eki team which will represent

The President of the Baltimore Ski Club and the Public

at the next meeting. Included in

a movie entitled "Ski Country
U.S.A."

Corps Volunteer
John L. Sipos, a graduate of
Hopkins with a degree in geography, has been named a Peace
Corps Volunteer, having completed 12 weeks of training at
Southern
Illinois
University,
Carbondale. Sipos departed for
Senegal on October 5.
The new Volunteers will teach
agriculture, woodworking and
metalworking in vocational
schools in the West African
country. They will be teaching
farmers who have had little
formal schooling and training
I uture Senegalese vocational
education instructors.
The Volunteers will supplement
the work of Peace Corps Volunteers already engaged in rural
community development in Senegal.
With the arrival of this group,
nearly 80 Peace Corps Volunteers
will be in Senegal, working in
urban and rural community development and physical education.
During training at Southern
Illinois University the Volunteers
learned French and studied
Wolof, an African language
spoken by many Senegalese.
They received instruction in
carpentry, metalworking, rural
construction,farm mechanics and
agriculture. They practiced their
teaching in vocational classes at
schools near the University.
The departing Volunteers join
the 10,000 other Peace Corps
Volunteers now working in 46
nations of Asia, Africa and Latin
America.

Leftist Talk
A talk on the "New Left" will
be given by Charles Capper at
Goucher College, this Thursday,
8:00 p.m., in the City Students
Lounge. Charles Capper, a student in history and English at
Hopkins, has contributed to the
leftist journals, Liberation and
New Politics. He is also a member of the Johns Hopkins Students for a Democratic Society.
This presentation is preparatory to a debate sponsored by the
Village Voice, in which Capper
will defend the "New Left" before a New York audience.

There will be a meeting of the
Graduate Organizing Committee
on Viet Nam this Sunday, October 31, 1965 at 7:30 P.M_ at the
Graduate Club in McCoy hall.
The following is an open letter
on the proposed amendment and
open meeting.
1) Whether or not we want to
restrict participation in the organization to graduate students
only, or whether we want to extend political citizenship to faculty and undegraduates as well.
2) What kinds of programs we
are going to undertake over the
next year; whether we are going to want to limit the educational programs of the committee
to bringing in speakers, sponsoring debates, etc., or whether we
want to forego the political
emasculation and leave ourselves
the opportunity for direct political advocacy (e.g. teach-ins,
marches, pickets, etc.)
When I use the term "we" I
am not referring to any preexisting elite cadre: there isn't
any, but rather the Johns Hopkins Graduate Student body as
a community. The meeting will
be entirely open: all graduate
students are invited.
There is no requirement that
you have any particular political
position on Viet Nam, or that
you know very much about the
war there. Few people in this
country do, including many socalled experts in the State Department. Just come. If you are
against the war, come. If you are
for the war, come. If you don't
know anything about the war,
but would like to find out more
than you know, come. If you
know quite a bit about the war

and would like to help educate
the rest of us, come. If you speak
foreign languages and would be
Interested in translating relevant
newspaper articles from foreign.
newspapers (e.g. LeMonde, L'Express, or Japanese, Chinese, or
German Newspapers) come. If
you like debates and political
arguments, come. If you get kicks
out of making posters, running
mimeos,
addressograph
miss
chines, come.

For Better • • •
The Johns Hopkins Magazine is not the made of
the stuff that most alumni magazines are made. By keeping a minimum to the majority of the usual alumni class
news, the magazine has consistently presented interesting and informative articles on virtually every topic. The
interest of the magazine has been to continue educating
the alumni; this concern has made it one of the finest
alumni magazines in the country. The articles, the photography, and the design of the magazine are unmatched by any other such publication and is reason
for the many awards that magazine has won during the
post ten years.
Tony Neville, the editor of the Johns Hopkins
Magazine, and his staff deserve to be encouraged to maintain this level of excellence.

... And For Worse
Last spring the library displayed several lithographs
by Robert Indiana. The library has removed them. Last
spring the library permitted its facilities to be used by
femmes from local colleges at all hours to closing. The
library has now removed them too. This situation makes
ns seriously doubt the esthetic sense, if not the sense of
community spirit (duty etc.), of the library staff. We
hope that these conditions can he amiliorated by the
return or replacement of factors of aesthetic interest.

A Brew For Hop-Goblins
The perversity of NIankind is at its hest on Halloween. For centuries, at this time of year, men have
aired their autumn folly, by celebrating and ritualizing
their peculiarities.
The Celtics are believed to have utilized Halloween
In placate the supernatural powers controlling the
processes of nature. They ritualized the practice of divination and its association with the dead, whose soles
were supposed to revisit their homes on that day.
The Scottish Halloween allows for a ritual which
M designed to determine who should marry who and
when in the coming year. It is conducted, by tradition, in
secret in a barn, where a sieve is used, by a young maiden
to perform the "act of winnowing corn." After repeating the performance three times the apparition of the
be seen in the cofigurafuture husband is supposed to '
ikon of the dispersed corn. The maiden is then, by custom, to go into the field at midnight to sow seeds of
Hemp while repeating this formula: "Hemp seed I sow,
let who will my husband he, let him come and mow..."
The allusions to mowing and sowing inevitably suggest
that after this final scene in the cornfield, the question
of who and when of marriage is given less to the whim
of the supernatural and given more to the dictates of
necessity.
Lately, the youth of America find in Halloween an
endorsement of the principle that by costuming, by
adopting a slight change in appearance, or by identifying with a perverse spirit, they are justified in pursuing
gleeful destruction.
The News-Letter endorses an alternative principle,
that perversity is best provoked, not by dressing the
part, but by eating its agitants; and in keeping with its
mission of realizing the abstract in terms of campus
eut+tom, the News-Letter has prepared the following
recipe for the provocation of local perversity and as a
guide to Halloween at Hopkins the Year round.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, OCTOBER 29, 1965

By HENRY J. KORN
On Sunday, October twentyfourth the Baltimore Sun reported that The United States
Army had alerted the Baltimore
Police to watch for the appearance of souvenir dolls popular
with our troops in Viet-Nam. The
dolls, described as "colorfully
costumed and about fifteen
inches long" were feared to have
been wired with explosives by
Viet Cong agents.
Later editions of the paper reported that the alert had been
canceled and that the Army had
called its bomb experts back to
the fort. Yet I question the wisdom of relaxing our guard. What
If some inscrutable oriental,
steeped in the tradition of Fu
Manchu and bitter tea, arose
from an opium stupor, slipped
into his basement laboratory to
perfect the newest ultimate
weapon; the dynamite BetsyWet-v.
World politics has long been
dependent on the concept of the
puppet. The Dolly, too, has had
a place in the history of international relations. Consider Mrs.
James Madison, who lived to see
her charred kitchen cabinet grow

doll with which he expected to
curse the United States. Clearly
the doll is coming to the fore
as a potent political force. It Is
hoped that the Mattel Company
stands ready to tool-up for government contracts. The Commies
might have Karl Marx for inspiration; thank God we have
Louie to deliver the goods!
Yet one cannot fail to notice
that the description of the
booby-trapped dolls coincides
with the Barbie Doll, which is
characterized with Boobies of its
own. Barbie, in many circles, has
become so important as to have
replaced St. Christopher on the
dashboard of the family car. The
gooks are doubtless waiting for

will Poetically invoke Chi Minh.

Grecian Gods Garb Gym Gear
By HocK
'

There has been great comment, in recent days, concerning
the two young stalwarts outside
the new Phys Ed center who
are supposed, in their uniquely
metallic way, to exemplify the
free spirit of sports. "I can't help
but wonder", its been said again
and again, why is not at least
one of these jolly green giants
a lacrosse player? Why indeed?
The answer, officially, is that
they are Greek gods, and represent all sport. Why then, one
must ask, are they wearing gym
shorts, and why can one detect
the name HutcH lightly cut into
the metal? The answer to the
gym short problem is a simple
one: while genuine Greek athletic garb was proposed, a combined part from the WCTU and
the DAR threatened immediate
action in the form of picketing
and mass public teetotaling to be
held at Homewood. The statues,
of course, were immediately redesigned. Still we are plagued
with the major problem, why is
there not a lacrosse player to be
seen at the National Lacrosse
Hall of Fame? The answer, at
last, can be revealed.
After much painstaking research, including extensive interviews with the sculptor, we have
found that there is not only one
lacrosse player in front of the
gym, there are two. Both of these
barefoot boys with cheeks are
lacrosse players. The truth, it
seems, lies hidden in history.
It has been supposed up to
now that the game of lacrosse
was invented by the Carlisle Indians in North America. Nothing
could be further from the truth.
Lacrosse is an ancient Greek
game, played originally in Sparta,.
It was used to harden Spartan
warriors, and was originally called Rubican, which roughly translated means Monopoly.
Rubicon was played in all the
Olympic meets, and the standard
Ruibcon uniform consisted of a
leaf. Leaves of different colors
were used to denote different
teams, and when multieblored
leaves were not available, as in
sand-lot Rubicon, they played
"shirts and skins". The game
was played on a square field
twenty dunams long, with goal
places at opposite corners. The

GREEK God wearing bronze gym shorts and Newsletter fig leaf.
field was called a Pythagoris, the
goals were called "legals" and,
the goalie was called the "legal
tender".
Each sport in Greece had its
patron gods, known as "patron
gods", who insured that the
game be played with little mishap, arid that the home team always win. Today they are called
refs. It is here that our two
"sportsmen" come in. While
most people assume that these
two statues are just arbitrary
figures, they are, in truth, the
ancient patron gods of Lacrosse,
Pyramid and Frisbee. Pyramid
and Frisbee were charged by
Zeus on high (the big man on
the god scene with a gear public
Image) with "creating a gayme
and playe at which the young
men of Greece might become
"experte," so that they might
take the Olympics in Tokyo the
following year. (The _quote is
straight from Zeus on high,
through his head press man,),.
Immediately they set to work,
and while Pyramid developed the
field, Frisbee set to work on the
implement to be used. He developed a flexible leather disk
with a net stretched inside it,
much like a leather discus. It
was to be held like a catcher's
mitt, and used for catching and

throwing the ball. It was named
after its inventor, and was called
a "Frisbee", it is that which the
statue is holding in 'his right
hand. Eventually the frisbee was
placed at the end of a stick, and
the modern lacrosse stick developed. With the hellanization
of the world the game spread,
and in Rome it was often played
between the Christians and the
Lions,with the Lions usually commanding Pythagoris most of the
game. A river was named after
It. It was in Rome that the
ten man team was developed
from the ancient Minyon principle. The positions were; legal
tender, left rear legionaire, center mauler, right rear legioner,
left center fielder, center fielder,
right center fielder rear skin,
midskin, and fore skin.
The game died with the conquest of Rome by the Goths, who
thought it was to archaic. The
name however, had been changed
in Rome to lacrosse, because it
was politically expedient. The
game somehow got to North
America via the trans-Atlantic
land bridge, where it was picked
up by the Indians, who thought
It would be a good way to dupe
settlers into coming out of their
fortified towns. The rest is, of
course, History.

TWELVE IS A MANY-SPLENDORED THING'
Today I begin my twelfth year of writing this column is
your campus newspaper.
These dozen years have passed like a dozen minutes. In
fact, I would not believe so much time has gone by except
that I have my wife nearby as a handy reference. When I
started this column,she was a mere slip of a girl—supple as
a willow bough and fair as the morn. Today she is gnarled,
lumpy, and given to biting the postman. Still, I count my.,
self lucky. Most of my friends who were married at the same
tirne have wives who chase cars all day. 1 myself have never
had this trouble, and I attribute my good fortune to the
fact that 1 have never struck my wife with my hand.I have
always used a folded newspaper, even during the prolonged
newspaper strike of 1961 in New York. During this journalless period [had the airmail edition of the Manchester Guardian flown in daily from England. I must admit, however,
that it was not entirely satisfactory. The airmail edition of
the Guardian is printed on paper so light and flimsy that it
makes very little impression when one smacks one's wife.
Mine, in fact, thought it was some kind of game and tore
several pairs of my trousers.
But I digress. For twelve years, I say, I have been writing this column. That is a fact, and here is another: I shave
every morning with Personna Stainless Steel Blades. I bring
up Personna Stainless Steel Blades because this column is
sponsored by the makers of Personna and they are inclined
to brood if I omit to mention their products.

the coaches."

Not,let me hasten to state, that it is any chore for me to'
sing the praises of Personna—as you will agree once you try
this sharpest,smoothest-shaving,longest-lasting blade ever
devised by the makers of Personna Blades—now available
both in Double Edge and Injector style. Personna, always
the most rewarding of blades, today offers even an extra reward—a chance to grab yourself a fistful of $100 bills from

is off and running,and you're all eligible to enter. Visit your

dealers, why don't you ask for a can of Burma Shave? It
comes in Regular or Menthol; it soaks rings around any
other lather,and it's made by the makers of Personna.
But 1 digress. For twelve years, I say, this column has
been discussing, forthrightly and fearlessly, such burning
campus questions as "Should students be allowed to attend
first-hour classes in pajamas?" and "Should deans be retired at age 25?" and "Should foreign exchange students be
held for ransom?".
Today,continuing the tradition, we take up the thorniest
academic problem of all: the high cost of tuition. Let me
tell you how one student, Lintel Sigafoos by name,solved
this problem.
Lintel, while still a boy in Straitened Circumstances,
Idaho, had his heart set on college, but, alas, he couldn't
afford the tuition. He applied for a Regents Scholarship
but, alas, his reading speed was not very rapid—only two
words an hour—and before he finished even the first
page
of his exam, the Regents had closed their briefcases crossly
and gone home. Lintel then applied for an athletic scholarship, but he had,alas, only a single athletic skill—balancing
an ice cream cone on his chin—and this, alas, aroused only
fleeting enthusiasm among the coaches.
And then he found the answer: he would get a
loan! Of course, he would have to pay it back after student
tion, but clever Lintel solved that, too: he kept graduahis major, never accumulating enough credits to changing
graduate
until he was 66 years old. Then he repaid the loan out
of his
Social Security.
Where there's a will, there's a way.

REPUBLICAN BIAS

Lindsay In New York
(Continued from Page 6)
good? Not really. 900, of the Republican vote going to Lindsay
means only 19% of the general
vote. The fact that Lindsay carries the title of Republican in
New York City indicates his intimate association with the 1929
Adams'
depression, Sherman
vicuna coat, Barry Goldwater,
the John Birch Society, H. L.
Hunt, Fisk and Gould's cornering of the gold market, and
touches of the Bubonic plague.
The unfortunate fact remains
that if John Lindsay wins in
New York City, the Conservative Buckleyite,s will claim that
he won in spite of the Republican Party, rather than because
of it. This is unfair and untruthful. The conservative party,
as well as most other third party
movements, are a menace to the
two party system. By imagining
themselves as Republicans, they
blemish the reputations of true
Republicans.
And
Mr.
O'Dougherty, chairman of the
Conservative Party, claims 30%
of its membership to be from
the Democratic Party. They appeal inherently to a minority
and thus do not have to face
issues realistically. Finally, they
have non-elected members and
therefore, do not have any responsibility to the public or electorate.
But what does the so-called
conservative Republican see in
the liberal Lindsay? Both Lindsay and Beame wish to eliminate
poverty, unemployment, defacto
segregation, educational deficiencies, housing problems, medical care problems, hospital shortages, crime, police difficulties,
and the overall decline of the
city. Both Lindsay and Beame's
proposals will cast as much and
probably will create or extend
the bureaucracy as much. But
the conservative New York Republican sees in Lindsay a break
with the past. By that I mean,
the hordes of Democratic political payoffs in building contracts,
painting contracts, the thousands of incompetent "good
Democrats" on the pay-rolls,
the bizarre handling of labor
strikes and the inability of the
corroded Democratic machine to
deal with the problems of the
city without selling its soul to
the wheeler-dealers in Washington or the state capital. Conservative Republicans are tired
of paying their tax bill so that

4111111111111•111111111116.

Theatre
Hopkins
presents

"The Killer"

a "Good Democrat's" mother
can remain in a city hospital
gratis, even though she can afford to pay. They are tired of
milk strikes, subway strikes, taxicab strikes, newspaper strikes,
and grave-digger strikes that
end in political deals with benefits only incidentally going to
the laborer.
Lindsay is not a conservative:
he is a liberal. Republicans are
not stiff, dogmatic, theorists.
They are human beings interested in good government for
their own self-interest. Therefore, the constructive conservative Republicans — and there
are miles of them who want to
strengthen the two-party system
—will vote for John Lindsay.
And if the day ever comes when
a Taft, Murphy, or Nixon have
as much broad support as Lindsay has in N.Y.C., the liberal
Republican will reciprocate and
cast his vote within the party.
The Republican Party is openminded. Do you recall that the
Democrats who supported Goldwater have been ostracized from
their Party? I notice, however,
people like Lindsay, Keating,
Javits, McKeldin, and Kuchel
are still active in the Republican
Party, and conservatives, like
Tower, Thurmond, and Reagen
are also maintaining their Republican identity.
New York City is known as
the. "ungovernable city." And
the New York voter is far from
stupid; he knows as Francis
Parkman wrote, "Where the carcass is, the vultures gather together." Therefore, a Johnson,
Humphrey, Kennedy, or Buckley
will not change the result of the
election. It will be Lindsay or
Beame and the Republicans
know their side.

THEATRE HOPKINS OPEN •
Dr. Fagin: College Drama Made Debut Last Night
Dr. N. Bryllion Fagin, Associate Professor Emeritus of English and Drama,
Stated in an interview Wednesday that
theatre and drama must be regarded
as an integral part of the humanities,
Lkd that the university must endeavor
to "keep alive" the traditions in the fine
The former chairman of the now
defunct Drama Department added that
College theatre is becoming increasingly
knportant as a "training ground for
the future."
Dr. Fagin was appointed Assistant
Professor 'of English after he obtained
kds doctorate in English here in 1932.
His interest in the theatre stems from
his early years in New York. He began
studying English at Michigan Agricultural College and later transferred to
George Washington University where
he obtained his BA in English. He then
attended Columbia for a short time
until finances caused him to return to
George Washington and attend afternoon classes while working for the government.
After getting his MA, Dr. Fagin came
to Baltimore to teach at the University
Of Maryland School of Medicine and
Dentistry. He became an instructor in
American drama at Hopkins in 1926
and was chosen as director for the
Playshop.
Pounded by the English department
in 1921, the Playshop existed primarily
for the purpose of providing quality
Plays for the faculty and student body.
It soon developed into a community
theatre when alumni began to return to
take active part in the various productions. Dr. Fagin ranks the Playshop as
setni-professional since he feels that
many of the actors are good enough
to play professionally. He recalls when
each year the Playshop would award
a Prize to the author in the group with
the best original play and maintains
that New York scouts would come to
review the productions.
Dr. Fagin was chairman of the Drama
department during the ten years of its
existence. It was abolished several years
ago, at the request of the English de-.
Partment, probably because of the qUes'Lion of expense necessary to maintain
a good graduate school in drama.
The Playshop had no connection with
the undergraduate Barnstormers. With
both groups sharing the Barn, some
Problems arose in schedule and budget
— the Playshop was not reeeiving subsidy and had to charge admission to
its productions. Dr. Fagin believes that
the Barnstormers has had a positive efrect on the undergraduates. For some
Years, members of the Barnstormers
With high aspirations would take
Courses from the Department and would
also work with the Playshop. This re-

stilted in an intermingling between the
two groups.
With the union of the two dramatic
organizations resulting in Theatre Hopkins, Dr. Fagin said that some things
have been lost — such as the group enthusiasm which the Playshop had. The
Barnstormers would change every four
years, while the Playshop had a "sense
of permanance" with its nucleus of permanent members. He does think, how-

Theatre Hopkins, under the direction
of Edward Golden, Jr., opened its initial
season last night with Eugene Ionesco's
"The Killer." The play, being presented
at the Barn, will run thru November 7.
Last spring, at a time when Hopkins
drama was in danger of being extinguished due to lack of support, administration officials, led by Dean G. Wilson
Shaffer and executive to the president
Ross Jones, obtained Golden to direct

THEATRE Hopkins began it's fall season last night with Eugene
Ionesco's "The Killer

ever, that the new group will be able
to produce more plays with a greater
versatility.
The greatest problem facing Theatre
Hopkins now is the need for better facilities. Although according to Dr.
Fagin, "There are good attributes connected with a small theatre," he said the
Barn is not flexible enough to provide
for the kind of experimental plays Mr.
Golden and the Theatre hope to produce. What he feels is needed is a new
small theatre of the Shakespearean
type.
Dr. Fagin does not expect any outside financial grant for a resident Hopkins theatre group, although he admitted that the donation of a new theatre
would be a great help.

Hopkins dramatics, and then gave him
their full support for establishing Theatre Hopkins. In a recent interview,
Jones stated, "The administration is enthusiastic about the idea of Theatre
Hopkins, and is also pleased with the
several plays produced last summer by
Rick Wesley. University officials are
hopeful that the new Theatre Hopkins
plan will result in a quality company
of benefit both to the University environment and the city in general."
The newly created Theatre Hopkins
is a synthesis of the Barnstormers and
the Playshop, last year manned by undergraduate and graduates, respectively.
Through the union of the two groups,
director Golden hopes to carry out
many theatrical innovations that he
was unable to implement at the Centre
Stage.
"The Hopkins communi0 is the hope

for a Baltimore theatre," he stated. "In
my experience, a good many of the
people who support cultural activity are
doing it because it is socially acceptable.
With respect to resident theatres,
Golden explained that "the problem is
that the theatre eventually goes begging to the complacent moneyed people.
The theatre than becomes subservient
and does not want to antagonize its
audience."
Professor Richard Macksey, of the
Writing Seminars, expressed his opinion that the academic community is
the one hope for experimental theatre.
He feels that the choice and sequence
of the plays to be presented especially
lend themselves of such experimentation. According to Macksey," The Days
and Nights of Beebee Fenstermaker' has
great potental — Mr. Golden exercised
good judgment in placing it at the end
of the year, when the less experienced
actors will have gained some of the
necessary background for the main
roles."
Macksey foresee:; that the potential
success of Theatre Hopkins may result
in a more permanent theatrical arrangement, possibly subsidized by the
Equity foundation or some other private
organization, or perhaps through the
Congressional Arts and Humanities Bill.
Such financial support would enable
the Theatre to employ some professional actors, and would present even greater opportunities for experiment.
From a purely practical standpoint,
according to Golden, the combination
of the Barnstormers and the Playshop
will alleviate many of the organizational problems encountered previously
when both groups were forced to produce plays into the Barn. In addition,
he believes that the inexperienced undergraduate actors will benefit from the
contact with the more experienced
members of the Playshop, which may
be considered as being on the semiprofessional level.
In addition to Theatre Hopkins, undergraduates will have the opportunity
to participate in two independently produced Barnstormer presentations, the
freshman play and Hopkins' latest musical, "The Boys from Syracuse."
While Theatre Hopkins will operate
during the fall and spring semesters,
the independent Homewood Summer
Theatre will present plays during the
summer months, completing the yearround schedule of theatrical performances presented on the Johns Hopkins
campus.
The. Homewood Summer Theatre
came into being last summer, largely
through the determined efforts of Rick
Wessler, currently a senior at Hopkins.
At that time it became apparent that
the annual summer Playshop would be
unable to function as it had for the
past thirty-four years due to the lack
of a director. Wessler secured permission from the Hopkins administration
to use the facilities of the Barn, and
with a total contribution from the faculty of $5.00, proceeded,to launch
successful season.

Corps Volunteer
John L. Sipos, a graduate of
Hopkins with a degree in geography, has been named a Peace
Corps Volunteer, having completed 12 weeks of training at
Southern
Illinois
University,
Carbondale. Sipos departed for
Senegal on October 5.
The new Volunteers will teach
agriculture, woodworking and
metalworking in vocational
schools in the West African
country. They will be teaching
farmers who have had little
formal schooling and training
I uture Senegalese vocational
education instructors.
The Volunteers will supplement
the work of Peace Corps Volunteers already engaged in rural
community development in Senegal.
With the arrival of this group,
nearly 80 Peace Corps Volunteers
will be in Senegal, working in
urban and rural community development and physical education.
During training at Southern
Illinois University the Volunteers
learned French and studied
Wolof, an African language
spoken by many Senegalese.
They received instruction in
carpentry, metalworking, rural
construction,farm mechanics and
agriculture. They practiced their
teaching in vocational classes at
schools near the University.

There will be a meeting of the
Graduate Organizing Committee
on Viet Nam this Sunday, October 31, 1965 at 7:30 P.M_ at the
Graduate Club in McCoy hall.
The following is an open letter
on the proposed amendment and
open meeting.
1) Whether or not we want to
restrict participation in the organization to graduate students
only, or whether we want to extend political citizenship to faculty and undegraduates as well.
2) What kinds of programs we
are going to undertake over the
next year; whether we are going to want to limit the educational programs of the committee
to bringing in speakers, sponsoring debates, etc., or whether we
want to forego the political
emasculation and leave ourselves
the opportunity for direct political advocacy (e.g. teach-ins,
marches, pickets, etc.)
When I use the term "we" I
am not referring to any preexisting elite cadre: there isn't
any, but rather the Johns Hopkins Graduate Student body as
a community. The meeting will
be entirely open: all graduate
students are invited.
There is no requirement that
you have any particular political
position on Viet Nam, or that
you know very much about the
war there. Few people in this
country do, including many socalled experts in the State Department. Just come. If you are
against the war, come. If you are
for the war, come. If you don't
know anything about the war,
but would like to find out more
than you know, come. If you
know quite a bit about the war

and would like to help educate
the rest of us, come. If you speak
foreign languages and would be
Interested in translating relevant
newspaper articles from foreign.

you like debates and political
arguments, come. If you get kicks

For Better • • •
The Johns Hopkins Magazine is not the made of
the stuff that most alumni magazines are made. By keeping a minimum to the majority of the usual alumni class
news, the magazine has consistently presented interesting and informative articles on virtually every topic. The
interest of the magazine has been to continue educating
the alumni; this concern has made it one of the finest
alumni magazines in the country. The articles, the photography, and the design of the magazine are unmatched by any other such publication and is reason
for the many awards that magazine has won during the
post ten years.
Tony Neville, the editor of the Johns Hopkins
Magazine, and his staff deserve to be encouraged to maintain this level of excellence.

... And For Worse
Last spring the library displayed several lithographs
by Robert Indiana. The library has removed them. Last
spring the library permitted its facilities to be used by
femmes from local colleges at all hours to closing. The
library has now removed them too. This situation makes
ns seriously doubt the esthetic sense, if not the sense of
community spirit (duty etc.), of the library staff. We
hope that these conditions can he amiliorated by the
return or replacement of factors of aesthetic interest.

A Brew For Hop-Goblins
The perversity of NIankind is at its hest on Halloween. For centuries, at this time of year, men have
aired their autumn folly, by celebrating and ritualizing
their peculiarities.
The Celtics are believed to have utilized Halloween
In placate the supernatural powers controlling the
processes of nature. They ritualized the practice of divination and its association with the dead, whose soles
were supposed to revisit their homes on that day.
The Scottish Halloween allows for a ritual which
M designed to determine who should marry who and
when in the coming year. It is conducted, by tradition, in
secret in a barn, where a sieve is used, by a young maiden
to perform the "act of winnowing corn." After repeating the performance three times the apparition of the
be seen in the cofigurafuture husband is supposed to '
ikon of the dispersed corn. The maiden is then, by custom, to go into the field at midnight to sow seeds of
Hemp while repeating this formula: "Hemp seed I sow,
let who will my husband he, let him come and mow..."
The allusions to mowing and sowing inevitably suggest
that after this final scene in the cornfield, the question
of who and when of marriage is given less to the whim
of the supernatural and given more to the dictates of
necessity.
Lately, the youth of America find in Halloween an
endorsement of the principle that by costuming, by
adopting a slight change in appearance, or by identifying with a perverse spirit, they are justified in pursuing
gleeful destruction.
The News-Letter endorses an alternative principle,
that perversity is best provoked, not by dressing the
part, but by eating its agitants; and in keeping with its
mission of realizing the abstract in terms of campus
eut+tom, the News-Letter has prepared the following
recipe for the provocation of local perversity and as a
guide to Halloween at Hopkins the Year round.

Grecian Gods Garb Gym Gear
By HocK
'

There has been great comment, in recent days, concerning
the two young stalwarts outside
the new Phys Ed center who
are supposed, in their uniquely
metallic way, to exemplify the
free spirit of sports. "I can't help
but wonder", its been said again
and again, why is not at least
one of these jolly green giants
a lacrosse player? Why indeed?
The answer, officially, is that
they are Greek gods, and represent all sport. Why then, one
must ask, are they wearing gym
shorts, and why can one detect
the name HutcH lightly cut into
the metal? The answer to the
gym short problem is a simple
one: while genuine Greek athletic garb was proposed, a combined part from the WCTU and
the DAR threatened immediate
action in the form of picketing
and mass public teetotaling to be
held at Homewood. The statues,
of course, were immediately redesigned. Still we are plagued
with the major problem, why is
there not a lacrosse player to be
seen at the National Lacrosse
Hall of Fame? The answer, at
last, can be revealed.
After much painstaking research, including extensive interviews with the sculptor, we have
found that there is not only one
lacrosse player in front of the
gym, there are two. Both of these
barefoot boys with cheeks are
lacrosse players. The truth, it
seems, lies hidden in history.
It has been supposed up to
now that the game of lacrosse
was invented by the Carlisle Indians in North America. Nothing
could be further from the truth.
Lacrosse is an ancient Greek
game, played originally in Sparta,.
It was used to harden Spartan
warriors, and was originally called Rubican, which roughly translated means Monopoly.
Rubicon was played in all the
Olympic meets, and the standard
Ruibcon uniform consisted of a
leaf. Leaves of different colors
were used to denote different
teams, and when multieblored
leaves were not available, as in
sand-lot Rubicon, they played
"shirts and skins". The game
was played on a square field
twenty dunams long, with goal
places at opposite corners. The

GREEK God wearing bronze gym shorts and Newsletter fig leaf.
field was called a Pythagoris, the
goals were called "legals" and,
the goalie was called the "legal
tender".
Each sport in Greece had its
patron gods, known as "patron
gods", who insured that the
game be played with little mishap, arid that the home team always win. Today they are called
refs. It is here that our two
"sportsmen" come in. While
most people assume that these
two statues are just arbitrary
figures, they are, in truth, the
ancient patron gods of Lacrosse,
Pyramid and Frisbee. Pyramid
and Frisbee were charged by
Zeus on high (the big man on
the god scene with a gear public
Image) with "creating a gayme
and playe at which the young
men of Greece might become
"experte," so that they might
take the Olympics in Tokyo the
following year. (The _quote is
straight from Zeus on high,
through his head press man,),.
Immediately they set to work,
and while Pyramid developed the
field, Frisbee set to work on the
implement to be used. He developed a flexible leather disk
with a net stretched inside it,
much like a leather discus. It
was to be held like a catcher's
mitt, and used for catching and

throwing the ball. It was named
after its inventor, and was called
a "Frisbee", it is that which the
statue is holding in 'his right
hand. Eventually the frisbee was
placed at the end of a stick, and
the modern lacrosse stick developed. With the hellanization
of the world the game spread,
and in Rome it was often played
between the Christians and the
Lions,with the Lions usually commanding Pythagoris most of the
game. A river was named after
It. It was in Rome that the
ten man team was developed
from the ancient Minyon principle. The positions were; legal
tender, left rear legionaire, center mauler, right rear legioner,
left center fielder, center fielder,
right center fielder rear skin,
midskin, and fore skin.
The game died with the conquest of Rome by the Goths, who
thought it was to archaic. The
name however, had been changed
in Rome to lacrosse, because it
was politically expedient. The
game somehow got to North
America via the trans-Atlantic
land bridge, where it was picked
up by the Indians, who thought
It would be a good way to dupe
settlers into coming out of their
fortified towns. The rest is, of
course, History.

TWELVE IS A MANY-SPLENDORED THING'
Today I begin my twelfth year of writing this column is
your campus newspaper.
These dozen years have passed like a dozen minutes. In
fact, I would not believe so much time has gone by except
that I have my wife nearby as a handy reference. When I
started this column,she was a mere slip of a girl—supple as
a willow bough and fair as the morn. Today she is gnarled,
lumpy, and given to biting the postman. Still, I count my.,
self lucky. Most of my friends who were married at the same
tirne have wives who chase cars all day. 1 myself have never
had this trouble, and I attribute my good fortune to the
fact that 1 have never struck my wife with my hand.I have
always used a folded newspaper, even during the prolonged
newspaper strike of 1961 in New York. During this journalless period [had the airmail edition of the Manchester Guardian flown in daily from England. I must admit, however,
that it was not entirely satisfactory. The airmail edition of
the Guardian is printed on paper so light and flimsy that it
makes very little impression when one smacks one's wife.
Mine, in fact, thought it was some kind of game and tore
several pairs of my trousers.

dealers, why don't you ask for a can of Burma Shave? It
comes in Regular or Menthol; it soaks rings around any
other lather,and it's made by the makers of Personna.
But 1 digress. For twelve years, I say, this column has
been discussing, forthrightly and fearlessly, such burning
campus questions as "Should students be allowed to attend
first-hour classes in pajamas?" and "Should deans be retired at age 25?" and "Should foreign exchange students be
held for ransom?".
Today,continuing the tradition, we take up the thorniest
academic problem of all: the high cost of tuition. Let me
tell you how one student, Lintel Sigafoos by name,solved
this problem.
Lintel, while still a boy in Straitened Circumstances,
Idaho, had his heart set on college, but, alas, he couldn't
afford the tuition. He applied for a Regents Scholarship
but, alas, his reading speed was not very rapid—only two
words an hour—and before he finished even the first
page
of his exam, the Regents had closed their briefcases crossly
and gone home. Lintel then applied for an athletic scholarship, but he had,alas, only a single athletic skill—balancing
an ice cream cone on his chin—and this, alas, aroused only
fleeting enthusiasm among the coaches.
And then he found the answer: he would get a
loan! Of course, he would have to pay it back after student
tion, but clever Lintel solved that, too: he kept graduahis major, never accumulating enough credits to changing
graduate
until he was 66 years old. Then he repaid the loan out
of his
Social Security.
Where there's a will, there's a way.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, OCTOBER 29, 1966

REPUBLICAN BIAS

Lindsay In New York
(Continued from Page 6)
good? Not really. 900, of the Republican vote going to Lindsay
means only 19% of the general
vote. The fact that Lindsay carries the title of Republican in
New York City indicates his intimate association with the 1929
Adams'
depression, Sherman
vicuna coat, Barry Goldwater,
the John Birch Society, H. L.
Hunt, Fisk and Gould's cornering of the gold market, and
touches of the Bubonic plague.
The unfortunate fact remains
that if John Lindsay wins in
New York City, the Conservative Buckleyite,s will claim that
he won in spite of the Republican Party, rather than because
of it. This is unfair and untruthful. The conservative party,
as well as most other third party
movements, are a menace to the
two party system. By imagining
themselves as Republicans, they
blemish the reputations of true
Republicans.
And
Mr.
O'Dougherty, chairman of the
Conservative Party, claims 30%
of its membership to be from
the Democratic Party. They appeal inherently to a minority
and thus do not have to face
issues realistically. Finally, they
have non-elected members and
therefore, do not have any responsibility to the public or electorate.
But what does the so-called
conservative Republican see in
the liberal Lindsay? Both Lindsay and Beame wish to eliminate
poverty, unemployment, defacto
segregation, educational deficiencies, housing problems, medical care problems, hospital shortages, crime, police difficulties,
and the overall decline of the
city. Both Lindsay and Beame's
proposals will cast as much and
probably will create or extend
the bureaucracy as much. But
the conservative New York Republican sees in Lindsay a break
with the past. By that I mean,
the hordes of Democratic political payoffs in building contracts,
painting contracts, the thousands of incompetent "good
Democrats" on the pay-rolls,
the bizarre handling of labor
strikes and the inability of the
corroded Democratic machine to
deal with the problems of the
city without selling its soul to
the wheeler-dealers in Washington or the state capital. Conservative Republicans are tired
of paying their tax bill so that

4111111111111•111111111116.

Theatre
Hopkins
presents

"The Killer"

a "Good Democrat's" mother
can remain in a city hospital
gratis, even though she can afford to pay. They are tired of
milk strikes, subway strikes, taxicab strikes, newspaper strikes,
and grave-digger strikes that
end in political deals with benefits only incidentally going to
the laborer.
Lindsay is not a conservative:
he is a liberal. Republicans are
not stiff, dogmatic, theorists.
They are human beings interested in good government for
their own self-interest. Therefore, the constructive conservative Republicans — and there
are miles of them who want to
strengthen the two-party system
—will vote for John Lindsay.
And if the day ever comes when
a Taft, Murphy, or Nixon have
as much broad support as Lindsay has in N.Y.C., the liberal
Republican will reciprocate and
cast his vote within the party.
The Republican Party is openminded. Do you recall that the
Democrats who supported Goldwater have been ostracized from
their Party? I notice, however,
people like Lindsay, Keating,
Javits, McKeldin, and Kuchel
are still active in the Republican
Party, and conservatives, like
Tower, Thurmond, and Reagen
are also maintaining their Republican identity.
New York City is known as
the. "ungovernable city." And
the New York voter is far from
stupid; he knows as Francis
Parkman wrote, "Where the carcass is, the vultures gather together." Therefore, a Johnson,
Humphrey, Kennedy, or Buckley
will not change the result of the
election. It will be Lindsay or
Beame and the Republicans
know their side.
